snippet: Some fear that a price-fixing lawsuit might give Amazon a pass to offer discounts that could put its competitors out of business.
abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column on how the Justice Department's price-fixing suit against Apple and the nation's top publishers will affect the nascent electronic book market; says that there is a belief that the suit will free Amazon to offer discounts that could put its competitors out of business, essentially creating a monopoly over the book market, but result will more likely be increased competition, something the media industry has long tried to limit.

snippet: A clip from “The Apple Pushers,” a film written and directed by Mary Mazzio, narrated by Edward Norton.
Companies that have prospered by spurning offers and remaining independent usually have a strong, informed board that is willing to stand up to both its chief executive and a hostile raider.
abstract: Companies that have prospered by spurning offers and remaining independent usually have a strong, informed board that is willing to stand up to both its chief executive and a hostile raider.

headline.main: In Judging Hostile Bids, Look at How Recent Targets Fared
headline.print_headline: In Judging Hostile Bids, Look at How Recent Targets Fared

snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Tuesday's selection includes an examination of the future of money, a dating couple finding common ground with an online video game and Twit...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Tuesday's selection includes an examination of the future of money, a dating couple finding common ground with an online video game and Twitter's reaction to Facebook's purchase of Instagram.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: IKEA TV and a Google Rival

snippet: The chip maker reported lower earnings in its first quarter, but said it expected a stronger second quarter on sales of cellphones and servers using Intel chips.
abstract: Intel reports lower earnings for the first quarter, but says it expects a stronger second quarter on sales of cellphones and servers using the company's chips; net income for the first quarter was $2.7 billion, or 53 cents a share, down 13.4 percent from $3.2 billion, or 56 cents a share, a year ago; revenue of $12.9 billion was up slightly from $12.8 billion a year ago.

headline.main: Intel Reports Flat Revenue, but Says Growth Is Ahead
headline.print_headline: Intel Reports Flat Revenue, but Says Growth Is Ahead

snippet: Twitter, in what it says is an act of good will to its engineers and designers, announced a new patent agreement that gives control back to inventors in potential patent legal suits.
abstract: Twitter, in what it says is an act of good will to its engineers and designers, announced a new patent agreement that gives control back to inventors in potential patent legal suits.

headline.main: Twitter Empowers Engineers With New Patent Agreement

snippet: The wearable computing wars are about to begin, a report released Tuesday by Forrester Research says, predicting that Apple, Google, Microsoft, Amazon and Facebook will help usher in the new era of computing.
abstract: The wearable computing wars are about to begin, a report released Tuesday by Forrester Research says, predicting that Apple, Google, Microsoft, Amazon and Facebook will help usher in the new era of computing.

headline.main: Wearable Computers Are the Next Big Devices, Report Says

snippet: A small publisher expresses concern about the government’s suit against publishers over e-book pricing. Readers are invited to respond.

headline.main: Invitation to a Dialogue: The Fight Over E-Books
headline.print_headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: The Fight Over E-Books

snippet: Stock markets on both sides of the Atlantic were encouraged by corporate profits, a well-received sale of government debt in Spain and a recovery in Apple shares.

headline.main: Stocks Climb on Profits and Spain’s Debt Sale
headline.print_headline: Upturn on Profits and Spain’s Debt Sale

snippet: Experts recommend the use of a "traffic light" control system in which fracking operations are suspended if a red light indicates seismic activity beyond a certain threshold.
abstract: Experts recommend the use of a "traffic light" control system in which fracking operations are suspended if a red light indicates seismic activity beyond a certain threshold.

headline.main: On Our Radar: Cautious Support for British Fracking
